title: In |x-1| + |x-2| + |x-3| < 6, what is the solution set of the equation? - Quora

response.answer_text: (1) Graphical method.  As can be seen from the graph, the solution is given by x values between the points A and B, thus [math]0 < x < 4.[/math] Note that the graph is split into 4 rays/line segments of AX, XY, YZ, ZB (2) Algebraic solution - There are four cases for each of AX, XY, YZ, ZB. (i) [math]x \le 1,[/math] then [math]x - 1 \le 0, x-2 < 0, x-3 < 0[/math] [math]\therefore \, 6 > |x-1|+|x-2|+|x-3|[/math] [math]=-(x-1)-(x-2)-(x-3)=-3x+6, \qquad \therefore x > 0 [/math] The solution in this domain is given by [math]\{x \le 1\} \cap \{x > 0\} = \{0 < x \le 1\}.[/math] (ii) If [math]1 < x \le 2, [/math] then [math]x - 1 > 0, x -2 \le 0, x - 3 < 0[/math] [math]\therefore \, 6>|x-1|+|x-2|+|x-3|=(x-1)-(x-2)-(x-3)=-x+4, [/math] [math]\therefore \, x < 2 [/math] The solution in this domain is given by [math]\{1 < x \le 2\} \cap \{x < 2\} = \{1 < x < 2\}.[/math] (iii) If [math]2 < x \le 3,[/math] then [math]x - 1 > 0, x - 2 > 0, x - 3 \le 0[/math] [math]\therefore \, 6 >|x-1|+|x-2|+|x-3|= (x - 1) + (x -2) - (x - 3) = x, [/math] [math]\therefore \, x < 6.[/math] The solution in this domain is given by [math]\{2 < x \le 3\} \cap \{x < 6\} = \{2 < x \le 3\}.[/math] (iv) [math]x > 3, [/math] then [math]x - 1 > 0, x - 2 > 0, x - 3 > 0[/math] [math]\therefore 6 > |x-1|+|x-2|+|x-3|= (x - 1) + (x -2) + (x - 3) = 3x - 6, [/math] [math]\therefore \, x < 4.[/math] The solution in this domain is given by [math]\{x > 3\} \cap \{x < 4\} = \{3 < x < 4\}.[/math] By combining (i), (ii), (iii), (iv), the solution is given by [math]0 < x < 4.[/math] Although the graphic solution is easy. It is pretty mindless.

In this case it is best to study the inequalities in four intervals for [math]x<1[/math], [math]1-x+2-x+3-x<6[/math], so [math]x>0[/math]for [math]1\le x<2[/math], [math]x-1+2-x+3-x<6[/math], so [math]x>-2[/math]for [math]2\le x<3[/math], [math]x-1+x-2+3-x<6[/math], so [math]x<6[/math]for [math]x\ge3[/math], [math]x-1+x-2+x-3<6[/math], so [math]x<4[/math]The solution set for case 1 is [math](0,1)[/math], for case 2 it is [math][1,2)[/math], for case 3 it is [math][2,3)[/math] and for case 4 it is [math][3,4)[/math]. Thus we can state that the full solution set is [math](0,1)\cup[1,2)\cup[2,3)\cup[3,4)=(0,4)[/math]  There is another fancy solution for this case: set [math]y=x-2[/math], so the inequality becomes [math]|y-1|+|y|+|y+1|<6[/math]. This inequality is invariant by changing [math]y[/math] into [math]-y[/math], so we can study it for [math]y\ge0[/math] and add also the “reflected” solution set. Thus we reduce to [math]|y-1|+2y+1<6[/math] that is, [math]|y-1|+2y<5[/math] For [math]0\le y<1[/math] this becomes [math]1+y<5[/math], so [math]y<4[/math], which is true; for [math]y\ge1[/math] it becomes [math]3y<6[/math], so [math]y<2[/math]. Hence the solutions for [math]y\ge0[/math] are the interval [math][0,2)[/math] and therefore we get the full solution set [math]-2<y<2[/math] that yields [math]0<x<4[/math].
